titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Annie Burr Lewis and Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Photographs
titlestmt.author: by Sandra Markham

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday March 14, 2019 at 01:00

did.unittitle: Annie Burr Lewis and Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Photographs
did.abstract: The Annie Burr Lewis and Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Photograph Collection consists of prints, negatives, transparencies, slides, and tintypes that provide visual documentation of the lives, family, friends, and activities of Wilmarth and Annie Burr Lewis. The images range from formal portraits by noted artists such Arnold Genthe and Yousuf Karsh, to hundreds of snapshots taken by friends and family, and by Annie Lewis herself. The material spans a full century in date, from a group of tintypes to photographs of family members through snapshots taken of Wilmarth Lewis before his death in 1979, but most of the images date from the first half of the twentieth century and cover the couple's childhoods through the death of Annie Lewis in 1959.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six series: I. Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis, 1895-1979. II. Annie Burr Lewis, 1903-1959. III. Wilmarth and Annie Burr Lewis, 1927-1958. IV. Family and Friends, 1859-1975. V. Places, 1860-1978. VI. Unsorted and Unidentified Images, 1900-1979.

bioghist.head: Annie Burr Lewis (1902-1959)
bioghist.p: Annie Burr Auchincloss Lewis was born in Newport, Rhode Island, on July 22, 1902, the daughter of Emma Jennings Auchincloss and Hugh Dudley Auchincloss. She attended Miss Porter's School in Farmington, Connecticut, and married Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis in New York in 1928. She died in Hartford, Connecticut, on May 9, 1959.

bioghist.head: Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis (1895-1979)
bioghist.p: Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis was born in Alameda, California, on November 14, 1895, the son of Miranda Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis and Azro Nathaniel Lewis. He attended the Thacher School in Ojai, California, and Yale University (Class of 1918). He met Annie Burr Auchincloss in Farmington, Connecticut, in 1923, and the couple were married in 1928. Together they spent three decades building a collection of books, prints, paintings, manuscripts, and decorative arts related to Horace Walpole, his circle, and his time, and formed a research library at their home in Farmington. Lewis died in Hartford on October 7, 1979; he left his home and collections to Yale University by bequest.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Annie Burr Lewis and Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Photographs. Lewis Walpole Library, Yale University.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Associated Material: Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 20). The Lewis Walpole Library.
Associated Material: Annie Burr Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 21). The Lewis Walpole Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Annie Burr Lewis and Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Photographs consists of prints, negatives, transparencies, slides, and tintypes that provide visual documentation of the couple's lives, family, friends, and activities. The images range from formal portraits by noted artists such Arnold Genthe and Yousuf Karsh, to hundreds of snapshots taken by friends and family. A good portion of the photographs were taken by Annie Lewis herself. She was an avid photographer and unfortunately, because she was behind the lens, images of her form only a small part of the collection—a rare photo of her posing with her camera in San Francisco in March 1939 can be found in the album in Box 31. Fortunately, however, Annie Lewis was mindful about captioning photographs, especially in the eleven albums she composed, and it is because of her careful work that many of the faces and places in the couple's picture collection can be identified today. She mounted prints in standard commercially available albums, but also created albums by affixing prints to pages in leather-bound volumes purchased as blank books or that formerly held Walpoliana collected by the couple.

The images span a full century in date, from a group of tintypes to photographs of family members through snapshots taken of Wilmarth Lewis before his death in 1979, though most are from the first half of the twentieth century and cover the couple's childhoods through the death of Annie Lewis in 1959. Both brought into their marriage, or later inherited, a variety of family photographs. Wilmarth Lewis, in particular, was the recipient of pictures and genealogical material owned by his brothers in California, which had been sent east by Charles, his only surviving sibling, prior to his death in 1969. The earliest item in the collection is not a photograph but the case that once held a daguerreotype or ambrotype of Annie Lewis's father Hugh Dudley Auchincloss (1858-1913) and his mother Elizabeth Buck Auchincloss, taken in 1859; the image itself is unlocated.

While much of the material in the collection is in black and white, there are many color photographs present. Notable are the approximately 250 sheet film transparencies and more than 600 slides taken by Annie Lewis, and from which she regularly had color prints made by the Pavelle laboratory in New York. Another remarkable group of color images exists in the two sets of stereo slides in the collection, which document the interiors of the Lewises' homes, the Major General Solomon Cowles House (1784) in Farmington, Connecticut, and the Jahleel Brenton farmhouse (1720) at Hammersmith Farm in Newport, Rhode Island. They are accompanied by a Realist Red Button stereo slide viewer which provides that format's intended three-dimensional effect.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Annie Burr Lewis and Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Photographs is the physical property of the Lewis Walpole Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the W. S. Lewis Librarian/Executive Director.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds portraits of Wilmarth Lewis made throughout his life, as well as photographs that document his involvement with various organizations, institutions, and groups. The first subseries, Portraits, contains images of Lewis photographed alone, by commercial studios or informally in snapshots by friends and family. The Activities subseries shows Lewis at dedications, conferences, dinners, and events, as well as receiving awards. Five folders at the end of the series contain snapshot photographs of him relaxing with friends and family, playing croquet, and posing with his beloved dogs.
Many additional photographs of Lewis appear in Annie Lewis's photograph albums in Series II, Boxes 29-32.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into two subseries: Portraits and Activities, and arranged chronologically thereunder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Four pages from an unidentified album with portraits and snapshot photographs of Lewis and family members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Date established by inscription on mat.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two photographs by Nina Leen - Pix, for Life magazine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Karsh studio files record Lewis's visit as sitting no. 9387, on November 24, 1944. The collection holds eleven prints featuring six different poses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Additional copies of prints housed in Karsh studio enclosures.

did.unittitle: Bruce Anderson sitting, University of Melbourne

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photograph by Meyers Studio of 1931 oil portrait of Lewis, which he left by bequest to the National Portrait Gallery in Washington, D.C. (NPG.80.8).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One of Scroll and Key members, and one unidentified group.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An unidentified group (Phi Beta Kappa?)

At Yale University Art Gallery alumni pictures exhibition

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also Annie Lewis's photo album in Box 31.

did.unittitle: At Yale for Morse and Stiles colleges dedication
At Smithsonian Institution art commission meetings
At Yale for Beinecke Library opening
At Yale for Kingman Brewster inauguration
At Yale Medal ceremony and Yale Commencement

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Lewis received the Yale Medal on February 20th, and was awarded an Honorary Doctor of Laws on June 14th.

did.unittitle: With Yale University Library staff at Farmington
At University of San Francisco for Gleeson Library Associates meeting
At University of Hartford for Mortensen Library dedication
At National Portrait Gallery, Washington, D.C.
At Yale University Library Associates event

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Some photographs have names and dates inscribed on verso but most do not. Also filed here are images of Lewis at Yale commencements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informal portrait in The Castle at Newport, by "Miss Sirkis."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds images of Annie Lewis photographed alone and in activities with friends and family. Her formal portraits start in infancy with images by the Alman & Co. studio, and continue with nationally prominent artists Curtis Bell and Arnold Genthe, and other professional studios in New York and Hartford. Also present in the Portraits subseries is a curiosity: a glass plate negative and two prints of a portrait painted by Ellen Emmet Rand which is similar to—but is not—the painting owned by the Lewises and now in the Lewis Walpole Library.

Compared with images of Wilmarth Lewis and friends in the other series, there are many fewer candid photographs of Annie Lewis engaged in activities, primarily because she was usually the one behind the camera.

As the eleven photograph albums in the Lewises' photograph collection were created by Annie Lewis, they are filed here although they hold images of both Lewises and their family and friends. Their contents were generally described at the item level for ease of access to images by location, event, or date. Many of the unidentified photographs in Series VI may be identified by checking images against those in the albums.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into three subseries: Portraits, Activities, and Albums, and arranged chronologically thereunder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three glass plate negatives with two images on each plate; they likely originated at the Alman & Co. studio in New York, and were used to make the series of platinum prints that are stamped on verso "Lee E. Paulmann Photographic Laboratories, Bristol, Conn."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Single sheet with portrait vignettes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder 4 holds two framed photographs: a portrait in a carved ivory frame, and in a mosaic frame, a candid photo of her with a small pig.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include one full-length pose, two seated poses, and a group portrait with bridesmaids; one of the latter images was annotated by Annie Lewis to identify her attendants. The setting is the home of her mother, Emma Jennings Auchincloss, at 33 East 67th Street in New York, where the wedding took place. The photographer is unidentified.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This portrait was used in publicity for the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform; also present is a three-quarter pose.

did.unittitle: American Red Cross portraits and photographs
In Cowles House garden with George Washington dumb stove

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This image was so favored by Wilmarth Lewis that he reproduced it in his autobiography One Man's Education . In the text he describes Annie Lewis setting up the camera so he could snap the photograph himself.

did.unittitle: In Cowles House garden with George Washington dumb stove

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two photographs of a painted portrait of Annie Lewis which is a variant of the portrait owned by the library. The painting's history and location are unknown.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One glass plate negative from which the above photographic prints were made.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A wooden box in which the glass plate negative was housed prior to 2016. The lid was inscribed in black crayon: "Glass Negative of Mrs Lewises Portrait"; inside is a folded section of the New York Times from April 26, 1936, which had served as padding for the plate.

did.unittitle: As a child, with friends and pets, and in travels

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Album pages with scenes in Newport, Fairfield, Scotland, and St. Augustine, Florida, with images of Annie Auchincloss and pets.

did.unittitle: Miss Porter's School theatricals and group photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Additional photographs of theatricals can be found in the Miss Porter's School photograph album (Box 26).

did.unittitle: As an adult, with friends and family

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A group portrait of attendants at the wedding of Caroline Parker to Staunton Williams in Cooperstown, New York, in July 1922. Annie Lewis labelled the print with names of some of the women who were friends from Miss Porter's School. She is not in the photograph, but Caroline Williams was an attendant in the Auchincloss-Lewis wedding in 1928.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Portraits and group portraits by Underwood & Underwood of Auchincloss and Jennings family members attending holiday dinners at the New York home of Annie Burr Jennings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Annie Lewis in a Spanish or Mexican costume worn at the 1926 Jennings Christmas dinner, posing with an unidentified man in formal wear; it is accompanied by a portrait, taken in the same location, of Azro Lewis, who is also dressed in Spanish or Mexican costume.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Annie Lewis kept a series of albums, with photographs arranged sequentially from 1896 through 1958, which document her travels and activities. Favorite places visited regularly include her two homes in Farmington and Newport; those of her relatives in Fairfield, Connecticut, and Jekyll Island, Georgia; and friends in Salisbury, Connecticut (Whitridge) and Conway, Massachusetts (MacLeish).

Another album, the Cowles House guest register, titled A Book of Hospitalities and a Record of Guests , is in the Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 20), Box 291. It holds a chronology of snapshots of friends and family who came to stay with the Lewises in Farmington and were photographed (likely by Annie Lewis) during their visit; the small-scale prints were then glued to the pages where the guests' signatures appeared.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The album opens with studio portraits of Esther, Hugh, and Annie Auchincloss (1896-circa 1903), and thereafter holds photographs of Annie's friends and views in France, Newport, Florida, Farmington, Fairfield, and at Mount Vernon (1910-1914). Laid in at the end of the album are circa 1910 photographs of three historic buildings in Annapolis, Maryland: the Peggy Stewart house, the Richard Carvel house, and the Chase-Lloyd house.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The album contains photographs taken at sea, in Egypt, France, Newport, Fairfield, Florida, and Farmington.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The album contains photographs taken on a family trip to the west coast, including scenes in Niagara Falls, Minnesota, Washington, British Columbia, and Alberta (June-July 1915); also with friends and family at Newport, Fairfield, and New Haven (August-October 1915), White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia (March 1916), Newport (June-September 1916), and Fairfield (October-November 1916).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A folding leather travel frame, gold-stamped with "ABA" monogram and "Made in France," accompanied by five photographs of friends formerly held within. The photographs are uncaptioned and unidentified.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The album opens with photographs of friends taken in Chester, New Hampshire, at New Year's 1917; the remainder of the album contains images of friends at beaches and at Miss Porter's School; most are not identified except for pages inscribed "Farmington Winter Term 1919" and "Spring Term 1919." There are two photographs of the theatrical production of Monsieur Beaucaire with Annie Auchincloss in the title role, and one group photograph of Miss Porter students.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The album contains photographs taken in Farmington and at Miss Porter's School.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The album contains snapshot photographs taken in Italy (March-April 1921), Spain (1922), England (1923), France, Switzerland, Italy, and Fairfield (1924), North Africa (January 1925), and Connecticut and Newport (1925). Also in the album is a watercolor view of the Bridge of Sighs in Venice, signed at lower right "G Marini." The album was likely purchased by the Auchinclosses in Italy in 1921 and contains a number of commercial photographs published by Italian and Spanish firms.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The album opens with the Auchincloss-Lewis wedding announcements clipped from New York newspapers followed by snapshots from wedding trips to Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, and Italy (January-March 1928), images of friends and family in Farmington, Southampton (NY), and Newport (1928), Farmington and Newport (1929), Farmington (1930), Farmington, Newport, France, and England (1931), and Farmington, Newport, Fairfield, and England (1932). The latter year includes views at Strawberry Hill, and the album concludes with a printed menu from the 1931 Johnson Club dinner at Pembroke College, Cambridge. A graphite sketch by Patty Bacon is laid in at the end of the album. The tooled leather album was made in Italy for the New York luggage firm Crouch and Fitzgerald.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The album opens with a photograph of Annie Lewis's needlepoint of Strawberry Hill, and continues with images of friends and family in Farmington, Colorado, Nevada, California, Massachusetts, Newport, and Long Island (1939); Farmington, Jekyll Island, Salisbury, Bedford, and Maine (1941); Farmington, Jekyll Island, Massachusetts, Washington, DC, Virginia, and Newport (1942-1946); Fiji, Australia, Hawaii, Farmington, and Newport (1947-1948).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The album opens with professional photographs of the New Library and dining room at the Cowles House; scenes in Farmington, Newport, and Massachusetts (1949); Farmington, Great Lakes cruise on the ore boat William A. Irvin , Newport, Yale Corporation, and portrait of A. Whitney Griswold (1950); Ireland, England, Farmington, Massachusetts, Newport, and Charleston (1951-1952); Farmington, England, Ireland, Newport, and Mount Vernon (1953); Farmington, Italy, Newport, Massachusetts, Vermont, New Hampshire, and the aftermath of Hurricane Carol (1954); Farmington, Ireland, England, Mount Vernon, and Newport (1955-1956); Charles C. Auchincloss dinner, with key to attendees (1956); England, Massachusetts, and Farmington (1958).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds portraits of the Lewises posing alone together.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder 3 holds a glass plate negative made in Venice; prints produced as real-photo postcards are in folder 2. Also present are film negatives from the Lewises' first stop in Rio de Janeiro, along with a paper slip used for ordering prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this photograph taken for Life magazine, the Lewises were posed next to their car in front of their house.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes portraits made in Farmington, Newport, California, England, Rio de Janeiro, and other places.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes both formal studio portraits and snapshot photographs of the Lewises' family members and friends. The folders for the couple's siblings may contain images from all stages of their lives as well as images of their children and grandchildren.

In addition to the photographs filed here, Annie Lewis's albums (Series II, Boxes 5, 25, and 28-31) contain many pictures of Auchincloss and Lewis siblings and their children. Auchincloss and Jennings family members attending Annie Burr Jennings's Christmas costume dinners can be found in Series II (Box 4, folder 19, and Box 22, folder 13).

Many other photographs of friends and family appear in the Cowles House guest register, A Book of Hospitalities and a Record of Guests , in the Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 20), into which Annie Lewis would paste her snapshots of friends and family who came to visit the Lewises in Farmington.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV is organized into four subseries: Auchincloss Family, Lewis Family, Unidentified Family Members, and Friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder 2 holds three items: a small portrait of Esther Auchincloss in silver frame; a small portrait of Hugh Auchincloss in a mosaic frame; and an empty leather case that formerly held either a daguerreotype or an ambrotype in half-plate format. The case is inscribed on the lining paper: "Hugh Dudley Auchincloss & mother/New York 9 April 1859/9 months old."

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Emma Jennings Auchincloss (1861-1942) was the mother of Annie Burr Lewis.

did.unittitle: Auchincloss Party, Colony Club, New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Panoramic photograph with key to attendees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Emma Brewster Jennings in her wedding dress, with sister Helen (?) or Annie.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs of Esther Auchincloss Nash Biltz and her children and grandchildren in the Nash, Dodge, and O'Brien families.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ruth Prentice Coffin Nash (1921-2007) was the wife of Edmund ("Ted" Nash (1918-2004).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographed in her wedding dress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three pages from unidentified album holding portraits and snapshot photographs of the Lewis and Cook families and residences in New Hampshire and Rhode Island.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: A niece of Wilmarth Lewis, Joan Maitland Lewis was the daughter of Martha Mohun Maitland and her first husband, and was adopted by Azro Lewis Jr. after his marriage to Martha in 1937.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Azro Lewis (1842-1913) was the father of Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis.

did.unittitle: Lewis, Azro Nathaniel Jr. and Martha

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Azro Lewis Jr. (1883-1957) was the third of Azro Lewis's five sons, and the first born to him and his second wife Miranda Sheldon Lewis. He married Martha Mohun Maitland Lewis (1900-1983) in 1937.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also Series II, Box 22, folder 14, for a portrait of Azro Lewis in a Spanish costume.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Charles Lewis (1885-1969) was the fourth of Azro N. Lewis's five sons, and the third born to him and his second wife Miranda Sheldon Lewis.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: George Lewis (1871-1951) was the first son born to Azro Nathaniel Lewis and his first wife Marie Antoinette Stillman.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Miranda Sheldon Lewis (1860-1922) was the second wife of Azro N. Lewis, and the mother of Azro, Charles, and Wilmarth Lewis.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ralph S. Lewis (1875-1946) was the second son born to Azro Nathaniel Lewis and his first wife Marie Antoinette Stillman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs of George, Azro, Charles, and Wilmarth Lewis engaged in activities together, including their 1908 camping trip in the High Sierras.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One portrait of Lewis and Cottrell family members at the Cottrell home in 1884, and a copy photograph of Lewis, Hall, and Wiggins family members in 1894. The latter image includes Azro and Miranda Lewis with their son George, and was taken at the Wiggins home, 3412 Washington Street, San Francisco on December 24, 1894.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twenty-one ferrotype photographs, primarily groups of young women, who are presumed to be family members. Nineteen are sixth-plate tintypes. Of the two half-plate images, one features eleven women and could be a school group (one holds a rolled document), and the second shows five women with a horse and carriage, and was captured on the street outside a clapboard building. There is one photograph of a child.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Portraits found in a box marked "family."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series hold professional portraits and snapshots of friends of the Lewises, including members of the Barney and Grummon families. Identifications were made through inscriptions on the verso by the sitter or by the Lewises.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes color transparencies and slides taken at the MacLeish home in Conway, Massachusetts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a formal portrait of Lee Stone by Arnold Genthe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes portraits of Dean Acheson, Max Beerbohm, Elizabeth Lee Beers, and Sir Owen Morshead.

did.unittitle: Other friends at Bissell dinner prior to the Paper Ball

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Four images of partygoers attending Marie T. Bissell's dinner in Farmington prior to the Wadsworth Atheneum's Paper Ball; they are copies of the prints found in Annie Lewis's photograph album in Box 29.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series V is organized in alphabetical order by state, and thereunder by city or town.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains views of houses and other locations owned or frequented by the Lewises and their relatives. The earliest images document two ancestral homes in San Francisco, but the bulk of the material pertains to the Lewises' two homes, the Cowles House in Farmington, Connecticut, and "The Castle" at Hammersmith Farm in Newport, Rhode Island. Formats include prints, negatives, color slides and transparencies, postcards, and stereo slides.

There are several sets of views of the interiors, exteriors, and grounds of the Farmington house and its additions, taken between 1935 and 1977 by professional photographers hired both by the Lewises and by magazine publishers. There are no professional photographs of the Newport house in the collection, with the exception of a set of color stereo slides by the New York-based architectural photographer Henry S. Fullerton 3rd; the slides provide the only known images of the home's interiors. Both residences were popular subjects for Annie Lewis over many years, so scores of images of each exist in the series.

Also present are photographs of the houses the Lewises occupied during their years in Washington, DC, and many views taken of other homes, gardens, and streets in Farmington. The series concludes with photographs taken during excursions abroad, in particular their visits to England. Many more photographs from those trips can be found in Annie Lewis's albums in Series II.

did.unittitle: Jennings residence, Essex Place between First and Second streets

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Rincon Hill residence of Oliver Burr Jennings (1825-1893) and Esther Judson Goodsell Jennings (1828-1908), the grandparents of Annie Burr Lewis, from 1860 to 1861. The photograph is not signed, and is accompanied by its contemporary gilt frame labeled by the maker, Thos. Robinson of 119 Washington and 134 Sansome St., San Francisco. The Jennings family relocated to New York in 1861.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A set of seven photographs documenting the residence of Miranda Wilmarth Sheldon Lux (1825-1894), a maternal great-aunt of Wilmarth Lewis. The mammoth plate albumen prints are by Runnels & Stateler, and include one exterior view, five interiors (entrance hall, dining room, parlor, music room, and library), and a view taken from the house's tower looking north up Gough Street to San Francisco Bay. The parlor photograph features on an easel a portrait of Charles Lux (1828-1887), the second husband of Miranda Lux.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A piece of red velvet found with the Lux photographs; it is likely from the "red plush album" holding the Lux photographs that Charles Lewis mentioned in a June 1, 1938, letter to his brother Wilmarth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dormy House, on Sasco Hill Road, was the residence of Emma Brewster Jennings Auchincloss (1861-1942), the mother of Annie Lewis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three photographs of gardens at the summer residence of Annie Burr Jennings (1855-1939), the aunt of Annie Lewis; two of the views are by Mattie Edwards Hewitt. Also present are six printed postcards of the house and gardens, including one featuring Annie Jennings standing in her rose arbor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Plate number 6409, from the complete statewide aerial survey made by Fairchild Aerial Surveys, Inc., in April and May 1934.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One from a set of images taken by Robinson Aerial Surveys, Inc., for the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Agriculture Stabilization and Marketing Service between October 1951 and June 1952.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also the album in Series II, Box 29, for photographs of the New Library taken in 1932 for the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The date of the series is established by a letter from Annie Lewis to Moreau Delano dated May 1, 1936, that was written on a series of photographic postcards of Cowles House exteriors and interiors; in the letter Lewis writes that she had just received the cards she commissioned from Chamberlain, and is "mad about them."

Chamberlain had photographed the Cowles House exterior for his Connecticut Tercentenary project "The American Scene," and it was used in the series of printed postcards of historic buildings found throughout the state. Annie Lewis asked Chamberlain to photograph inside the house in fall 1935 (see Annie Burr Lewis Papers, LWL MSS 21, Box 4, folder 2), and his negatives are filed here. Her letter to Delano is in the Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 20), Box 33, folder 8. A second set of Chamberlain's photographic postcards is in Charles Lewis's scrapbooks (LWL MSS 20), Box 277, folder 2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photograph taken for The Colophon .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two photographs by Nina Leen - Pix, for Life magazine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eleven glass stereo slides with color images: five of the New Library, three of the Old Library, and three of the Morning Room; the photographer is unknown. Also in the box is the Lewises' Realist Red Button stereo slide viewer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three mounted and signed prints of the Cowles House bearing the Stoller record numbers 143L 1-2, and 83L 1. Two are views of the front exterior and one was taken in the Morning Room. They were comissioned for Richard Pratt's article in Ladies Home Journal , and reprinted in his series of "Treasury of Early American Homes" books.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes one photograph of Wilmarth Lewis in library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains photographs of the "America" and "Columbia" (or "Lady Liberty") statues after installation in the Cowles House gardens, with images of "America" prior to its move to Farmington. Also present are snapshots of the sculpture "New Life" by Mary Knollenberg, which was also installed on the grounds.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: John Auchincloss (1810-1876) and Elizabeth Buck Auchincloss (1816-1902), the grandparents of Annie Lewis, purchased seaside property in Newport in 1852, and built a home there in 1857. When Hugh D. Auchincloss (1858-1913) and his wife Emma Jennings Auchincloss (1861-1942) inherited Hammersmith Farm, the house had been replace by a large shingle-style home (built 1888-1889). Upon Emma's death, their children divided the property. Hugh Jr. (1897-1976) acquired the main house and Annie Lewis took a smaller gambrel-roof eighteenth-century house (the Jahleel Brenton farmhouse, 1720). Known as "The Castle," it was renovated by the Lewises and they spent their summers there.
A photograph of the 1857 house and a view of the grounds to the harbor can be found in a published memorial to Elizabeth Buck Auchincloss (under library call number 5756 Au898 902).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twelve glass stereo slides of "The Castle": one exterior view, three views of the living room, two of the dining room, two of the library, and two each of the two bedrooms. The photographs were taken by Henry S. Fullerton of Westfield, New Jersey, an architectural photographer known for his documentation of the Kennedy White House and the work of several New York interior decorators. Also in the box is the Lewises' Realist Red Button stereo slide viewer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes color transparencies and seven printed postcards with views of the house and gardens. Photographs and paintings of the gardens appeared in Country Life in America 30 (June 1916): 40-43.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily documentary photographs of buildings and gravestones of historical interest; many were taken by author and architectural historian William King Covell.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes color slides taken by Annie Lewis and six commercial slides purchased there.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of the exterior and library of Robert Wyndham Ketton-Cremer's home; the images include slides from the Lewises' 1955 visit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: For earlier and additional photographs of Strawberry Hill, particularly those relating to building repairs and restoration, see the St. Mary's College correspondence folder in Series I of the Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 20).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In addition to prints, the folder holds color transparencies of the Lewises' 1951 trip to England, and slide sets of their 1954 trip to Italy, their 1955 visit to The Vyne, Lady Reading, Stokesay Castle, Syon House, Strawberry Hill, and Cambridge, and their 1957 trip to England and Scotland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains negatives, with some prints, which were found in their original commercial processing envelopes inscribed by Annie Lewis. They were arranged in groups by date or by subject. Filed at the end are images of unidentified people and places, including unidentified friends photographed at the Lewises' homes in Farmington and Newport. Any inscriptions made by Annie Lewis were transcribed as file titles, or appear in notes at the folder level.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series VI is organized into two subseries: By Date, and By Subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The SS William A. Irvin was the flagship of the United States Steel Corporation's lake freighter fleet. In service on the Great Lakes from 1938 to 1978, she hauled iron ore from ports on Lake Superior to U.S. Steel mills on lakes Michigan and Erie. Guests of Irving Sands Olds (1887-1963), the chairman of U.S. Steel from 1940 to 1952, were able experience the same journey in the ship's luxurious passenger quarters. The folder holds color transparencies, negatives, and prints from a trip taken by the Lewises in August 1950. Prints from the Lewises' cruise with the Sherrills can be found in the album in Series II, Box 31.
